entry.title: AI Does Not An Author Make

link.title: AI Does Not An Author Make

entry.content:
Today I woke up sprawled out on my couch because I once again passed out while watching Youtube. This is a new trend for me as I inch closer and closer to 40. But, I got up, slapped some food into a bowl for my cat, and then turned on the milquetoast social media, and immediately saw more aggravating takes from people who don‚Äôt deserve attention, or any money whatsoever. I‚Äôm talking about plagiarists who are desperate to be called authors; AI loving losers who think you should definitely expel energy to read things they didn‚Äôt even have the energy to write themselves.

This comes on the heel of more irritating news, as Mozilla ignores thousands and thousands of their users criticizing their implementation of AI into Firefox (for no verifiable reason whatsoever), because obviously they‚Äôre more interested in the destruction of Mozilla, than continuing to be a privacy focused company. I have since moved to Vivaldi, a browser by a company that has pledged not to implement AI into their browser.

But, back to the point at-hand, I want to highlight this article specifically, because I can only take so much inauthentic douchebaggery before I have to really express my thoughts. And that‚Äôs saying a lot, because most of corporate social media feeds off of being inauthentic and fake.

Post by @theinformation
View on Threads


Opinion: Johnny Silverhand should materialize into the real world and explode AI content farms.

Let‚Äôs not even talk about the Threads account of a publication that has such a basic name that it‚Äôs gotta be AI generated (we‚Äôre ‚Ä¶ THE INFORMATION), but into the article itself where the featured image, some glossy ai-generated sludge, is attributed to the same guy who‚Äôs writing about how great it is to plagiarize actual writers in order to write a book. To add insult to injury, you can‚Äôt even read his word-vomit without paying him and/or the website for a subscription. Like the desperation of a teenager right before prom, these complete hacks who think they can technology their way into being a part of the creative world, they‚Äôre dead-set determined to make money off of you, somehow, some way.

So, because the article is paywalled and I‚Äôm too groggy to sift through their code in order to delete it, we‚Äôre just going to talk about the snippet you‚Äôre allowed to see before it cuts off and demands ‚Ä¶ ah, a minimum 300 dollars per year. Yeah, no. Put me in a Saw trap in a dirty bathroom, chained to a wall with a rusty bone saw and I‚Äôd sooner remove my own foot than pay you.


Ripped directly from the RSS feed:

Tim Boucher is an artist and technologist who explores the intersection of artificial intelligence and human creativity.

I set up a Google Alert on my name so long ago that I‚Äôd almost forgotten about it. It occasionally sends me stories about people in faraway places who share my first and last names. But the alert I received in mid-August was different.

When I opened the email, I realized that this was really about me: My work had been referenced in a class action lawsuit against Anthropic, a leader in generative artificial intelligence. I am not party to the lawsuit, but it claims that my work is not real ‚Äúwriting‚Äù (scare quotes and all) and that I am not a real author, because I use generative AI, among other tools, to produce my books. No one involved in the lawsuit reached out to me for more information; I would have been happy to share.

‚ÄúTim Boucher is an artist.‚Äù I wouldn‚Äôt go that far, insulting artists by giving Tim credibility. But, right from the get-go, this guy is expressing his extreme need to feel important, or like he‚Äôs done something, by immediately detailing that he‚Äôs setup Google Alerts to let him know when people have mentioned his name online. Tim Boucher, come read what I‚Äôve written about you, you fake piece of crap.

He starts out talking about how he was essentially being sued for using AI to pump out sludge-books. And, to whomever said his writing was not real, I applaud you. You should do it again.

Since that‚Äôs around where it cuts off, I‚Äôm assuming the article is less about Tim trying to feel validated in being a plagiarist hack, and more him writing a defense he‚Äôll use in the court of law, where he‚Äôll be forever shamed. I‚Äôm just going to use this as a jumping off point to share the rest of my feelings on this matter. A matter I wish wasn‚Äôt a matter, but we‚Äôre living in the worst and also most boring cyberpunk dystopia imaginable.

They‚Äôre right, Tim. You are not a real writer, you are not a real author, and you haven‚Äôt done anything of note.

Anyone who uses theft-tech to generate words that they can publish for a quick buck is not a damn author. You are no better than Microsoft Tech Support scammers ripping off elderly people of their retirement money. You have done nothing. You did not write anything. You used a machine that has scraped the entire internet of every word an actual human has written, in order to generate a discombobulation of words that you hope someone will think is interesting.

But I‚Äôm here to say, fuck you.

It‚Äôs because of people like you that the world of self published writing will be even worse off, and will be continued to be considered lesser than big house publishing. Because of uncreative, losers, flooding the market, flooding apps with shit. Before, we were only competing with people who refuse to proofread. Now we‚Äôre competing with people who refuse to proofread, and also people who refuse to read and write.

I wish I was making this up.

I wish I hadn‚Äôt started writing my next book literal months before this started to become a problem. I wish I would‚Äôve written it years ago, so that I could‚Äôve gotten it out, and finished in an era where I could still share snippets and previews online, without needing to worry about machines taking every word and rearranging it for people who should go broke and live in the gutter.

That‚Äôs how I feel.

No-holds-barred, if you use AI to generate art and fiction, you deserve the worst. And no less than that.

Fortunately, like NFTs, AI is a bubble, and when it finally pops, the results will be amazing, hilarious, and great. And then the general internet will forget any of this happened three days later.

entry.title: Illusion Connect Will Return?
entry.content:
It was 2020, my rotation of mobile games included just two of them. I had a phone that could support ‚Ä¶ maybe three? One of them was the already very well-known Orc game, and the other was a little gacha called Illusion Connect. Okay, so, if you aren‚Äôt really interested in gachas, and you think buying stuff in them sucks, this probably isn‚Äôt all that interesting to you.

But, today it was revealed, that almost two years after it‚Äôs closure, Illusion Connect is returning this winter.

This was my main mobile game for a long time. The thing is, like with most mobile games, I stop playing them for a while, and then I come back and continue. It‚Äôs a pattern with me, and not really any inherent issue with mobile games in-general. I treat triple-a desktop games exactly the same way. I‚Äôm super into Warframe, but I haven‚Äôt opened it in two weeks, because I just ‚Ä¶ have so much going on in my brain-juice.

So I had that little cooling off period, and after a while, I decided I wanted to open it up again and see how things were going. And then in December, 2022, it abruptly shutdown. Leaving you with nothing but an error screen as if it still exists, it just couldn‚Äôt connect to the servers.

Since then, I‚Äôve been kind of meandering through these other gacha games that don‚Äôt really capture the same thing, or the same fun I had in my little phone game of anime girls. Albeit, Genshin, ZZZ, Wuthering Waves are all great. There‚Äôs just ‚Ä¶ something also good about a game that isn‚Äôt trying to be a huge open-world mega gacha experience. And that‚Äôs what Illusion Connect was. A simple thing you logged into, tapped some objectives, collected your stuff, pulled, and then logged off.

I like mobile games like that. Something I can open secretly while I‚Äôm walking through the halls at work, click a box, watch it open, and then shove my phone back into my pants.

But anyway, here‚Äôs the announcement.

For those who can‚Äôt read Chinese, (like me), here‚Äôs the translation:


Suffice to say, the developers have apparently been rebuilding the game, and that‚Äôs cool! It‚Äôs cool when an online game of sorts isn‚Äôt just abandoned, and instead worked on, rebuilt, and then relaunched, even after an unfortunate closure. A lot of big studios should take notes here ‚Ä¶

Still mad I bought into The Matrix Online two decades ago in order to lose all my stuff, and my character, forever.

entry.title: Cohost is Shutting Down
entry.content:
Yesterday, on September 9th, 2024, it came across my timelines that Cohost, one of the few Tumblr alternatives, would be shutting its doors at the end of the year, and going read-only on October 1st. I‚Äôve been a huge advocate that people join and use Wafrn as a Tumblr alternative, largely due-in-part to the fact that Wafrn is fediverse connected, and therefore a lot of the stress of server costs are offloaded into that connection. Not only that, but should Wafrn ever close its doors, every single user is fine, since you can just move to another fediverse server, with most of your data in-tact. Despite all of that, it is sad to see something that was pretty cool, go away.

Since the beginning they‚Äôve been proponents of ‚Ä¶ an isolated social experience, dressed up to look like a website from 1997. Which is cool (the part about looking like it‚Äôs from the nineties)! But, like I keep saying in every other post, federated social media controlled by users, and not corporations, is the future. Being regular people who aren‚Äôt a corporation who happened to get together as a group of 4, in order to develop a social media website, is pretty neat. I‚Äôll give them that.

But, since the general vibe of Cohost has been to avoid federation, at all costs, and keep users within this walled-garden of sorts ‚Ä¶ well, I guess all that community building is also finished.

I‚Äôm not trying to rub salt in the wounds of people who are upset about this. Cohost was genuinely good. It definitely wasn‚Äôt Bluesky, which, since launching, has been nothing but a monster in the room that says and does questionable things, while other people pretend it‚Äôs the only choice. And, I actually really wanted to like and use Cohost, but I‚Äôm so tied in on federation, that it just made no sense at all to me to really take serious. Just like with SpaceHey, the Myspace revival project ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt really have any interest in sharing my thoughts, ideas, and projects on an isolated website, in 2024, just so I can also go share it on the website that isn‚Äôt isolated.

Reducing repetitive action is necessary, because, if you‚Äôre a creator, you do stuff like this a lot, and time isn‚Äôt cheap, and I don‚Äôt have a lot of it nowadays.

But, for people who are just online to share thoughts, and didn‚Äôt really have any other place they posted them in, I‚Äôm sorry. I wish I had a million dollars or two in order to save this website. It really does suck a lot to see the good ones go, when the bad places are still up and running and have yet to die (TWITTER!).

As an alternative action for those who I‚Äôve seen via Cohost talking about how it was, to them, the only safe place online they felt they could express themselves, I urge you to create a website here on Neocities. It doesn‚Äôt even have to be professionally designed or perfect, but just make a website. Design it any way you please, and set it up in a way that allows you to speak. I think you‚Äôll find that being able to share you thoughts on something you built, for free, and without threat of any servers dying is pretty fun. And, at the end of the day, everything you create for a website should be backed up on your PC, effectively making it impossible for your data to be destroyed (I also back up my websites in multiple cloud locations, just in case).

Those are my thoughts, though, aside from being confused at how Stripe‚Äôs policy change on tipping caused all of this. Surely, you could still offer a site-wide currency in order to generate revenue, and just give people who buy it some kind of fake little digital thing for their blogs so that it‚Äôs no longer a payment for what Stripe essentially sees as nothing. I don‚Äôt know, maybe the problem runs deeper than that.

entry.title: Plant Your Own Garden
entry.content:
Today, I spent the equivalent of around ten hours of work (on my day off, no less), designing and developing a new kind of ‚Äúside service‚Äù I wanted to offer to people who: Don‚Äôt have the time, or don‚Äôt want to learn HTML and CSS, and who want to separate themselves from corporate media, just a little bit, even if it‚Äôs just to stop paying services like Linktree a monthly fee.

So, today I am unveiling, LinkGarden.

Plant your own garden ‚Ä¶ of links!

I detail the service on the page, but I‚Äôll write about it here, as well, except, maybe in a more extended fashion. I‚Äôm offering this for eighty bucks. You pay me, then contact me, and I‚Äôll get your page together, and even make you a Neocities where it can be hosted (hosted, completely for free). Of course, once I hand over the credentials, you‚Äôll be responsible for changing your password. But, that‚Äôs a given!

You can request to use a custom domain, but this is a little more involved, in that, we‚Äôll need to figure out if you‚Äôre buying the domain, and if you know how to setup the DNS. If not, I certainly know how to do this, but I also don‚Äôt have access to your domain admin panels.

I‚Äôm doing this, though, because, I want to show people that they can have all the frills of a Linktree, without a Linktree. I can do it for you, easy-peasy, and in about an hour.

Now, obviously, if you want really extensive, or more complicated stuff (more javascript, animated buttons that do more than just click and highlight, and so on and so forth), that would obviously take more than an hour to setup. Then, yes, we‚Äôll have to negotiate pricing a little bit (right now my day job takes up so much of my time it‚Äôs ridiculous). Consider this though, if you currently pay monthly for a Linktree, or some other such service, and you‚Äôve been doing so for a long time, how much have you paid them, in total? Probably less than what it‚Äôd cost for me to do this for you, right?

But I‚Äôm also doing this, because you should own your own piece of the internet. A place where a bunch of suits aren‚Äôt tracking your every move, where people can come and see what you‚Äôre all about, quickly, and easily. Maybe sometime in the future I‚Äôll offer to build people entire websites! But, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a venture I want to spend another ten hours preparing right now (I have some people in VR I want to visit tonight).

Once you have the page, and access to it, if you decide you want things changed, I can also do that. But, I would encourage buyers to look into the code used to build their link pages, and see if you can fiddle with changing things yourself (learning is fun!). I have them all setup with the simplest CSS and HTML possible, and if you use a program like VS Code, switching colors around in a CSS file is even easier. And, if you mess things up, I will have a backup of everything I do right here on my PC.

So, come on over, and plant your own garden.

entry.title: I Gave Buffer a Shot: I Have Thoughts

link.title: I Gave Buffer a Shot: I Have Thoughts

entry.content:
A while back, I put up a post about Bluesky announcing their partnership with cross-posting company, ‚ÄúBuffer‚Äù (Yes, I‚Äôm aware that it‚Äôs starting to look like I have multiple topics that are an ongoing series on this website). I also detailed how this was a bad move, because Buffer is using OpenAI tech in their backend, and even though they say it‚Äôs just an option you can utilize with writing posts ‚Ä¶ based on how OpenAI has been conducting themselves, I don‚Äôt fully trust any company that thinks it‚Äôs a good idea to use their tech. Regardless, since I run a lot of different social media accounts, and I thought it could make things easier for me, like when I write blog posts, or have new music, I decided to give it a whirl!

Here are my thoughts.


The website itself is very well organized, you can connect your socials, and it even has a calendar that displays ‚Ä¶ everything you‚Äôve ever posted on your connected accounts, chronologically by time and date (which ‚Ä¶ is actually pretty worrying if you don‚Äôt think they‚Äôre using that OpenAI tech ethically), and you can do a few other things. Such as, you can create a ‚Äústart‚Äù page, which is just a rip of Link-tree. The downside, is that creating a Buffer version of Link-tree takes up one of your social connections.

But, how many are you allowed to connect on a free account?

Three.

Or, if you want a page with all your links provided by Buffer, essentially, you can connect two accounts.

So, basically, if you‚Äôre using the free Buffer plan, you may as well not even be there. If you can‚Äôt manage two accounts without the help of some software ‚Ä¶ geez, dude.

Okay, but how much does it cost to upgrade to have more connections.

Short answer: Way to goddang much.

Long answer:

You can actually opt to start paying them fifteen dollars a month for the three accounts you‚Äôve already connected, and have a few added features. Or, you can connect four accounts for twenty dollars, or five accounts for twenty-five dollars, or ‚Ä¶ a whopping fifty dollars for ten accounts! For a frame of reference, I have around eleven or twelve accounts I use across different networks, some alts, some not-so-much. They say, on the subscription page, that this is all ‚Äúthe most value for an individual creator ‚Ä¶‚Äù

An individual creator? Paying, fifty dollars a month for ten accounts, as long as you‚Äôre paying on a yearly basis.


Bro ‚Ä¶

Okay, so obviously this has gotta be some kind of marketing that‚Äôs specifically targeting creators who are already making money from what they do online. For fifty dollars a month, if paid yearly, or sixty dollars on a monthly basis, for ten accounts, you could, instead, subscribe to Apple+ and Netflix, and have some entertainment instead. And then just manage your accounts yourself. All with the added benefit of not potentially feeding everything you‚Äôve ever posted into some OpenAI crap.

Which, take a look at this: Are mentioned multiple times on the publishing and scheduling box.


‚ÄúUse AI assistant!‚Äù Also, did you want help publishing with the ‚ÄúAI Assistant?‚Äù

Because everyone on social media knows that using AI to generate your words totally doesn‚Äôt make you look like a completely fake tool-bag.

So, instead of using Buffer, I‚Äôve opted to just manage the couple of accounts I use the most ‚Ä¶ myself. No, you guys aren‚Äôt getting fifteen, or twenty, or fifty dollars out of me.

But, I did really like their ‚Äústart page‚Äù link aggregator. And, since they‚Äôre so hyper-vigilant about AI generated plagairism, I‚Äôm sure they won‚Äôt mind if I just ‚Ä¶ rip out the code of their link page, delete all the link trackers, place the CSS into its own file (because why the hell do you have it on the same page as the content?), rename all the modules to something humorous, enlarge the profile picture, increase the vertical size of the banner gif, change all of the colors, replace their icons with Phosphor icons, and replace their crappy static ‚Äúupdate‚Äù section that doesn‚Äôt even serve clickable links, with ‚Ä¶ A live feed of my blog‚Äôs RSS (courtesy of Brenton Fletcher‚Äôs rss.bloople.net)

See it, here: CMDR Nova‚Äôs Linkgarden.

Buffer version on the left, my version on the right.


But here‚Äôs the thing, if you really want, or need a page of all of your links that you can easily just hand to someone like a business card, you can build one yourself, or, if you really don‚Äôt have the time, or want to learn HTML and CSS, I can just make it for you. I‚Äôm actually going to put together some examples of what a ‚Äúlinkgarden‚Äù could look like if I made one, and gave it to someone, and provide information on free hosting. Or, hey, maybe I could set that up for people too?

I don‚Äôt know.

What I do know, is that you don‚Äôt have to pay companies continuously for something that can be made for you in a couple of hours, or that you can make yourself in a couple of hours, and then have full control over. And if you really need automated control of all of your accounts at once, I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs a better way to do it, than paying some company that‚Äôs gone all-in on AI, six hundred dollars a mother-frikken year.

entry.title: Social Media, Empathy, Caring About Other People?

link.title: Social Media, Empathy, Caring About Other People?

entry.content:
I feel like this is something I want to write about here on the Nova Prime, not because it‚Äôs a joyful topic, or something that makes me happy, but because it‚Äôs an overall larger issue that I think‚Äôs been carried over from a website that‚Äôs trained a lot of people to kind of, mentally ‚Ä¶ disregard others, at all expense, for their own personal gain, or comfort. Am I saying that Twitter has accidentally spawned masses of narcissists? Not really. I don‚Äôt think a website and its use for over a decade can alter someone‚Äôs brain chemistry. Or ‚Ä¶ can it?

But this is more about Bluesky, because, yes, again, we are seeing some undue angst and toxicity being slung toward the federated social network revolving around ActivityPub, or more exclusively, Mastodon, because a lot of these people don‚Äôt know about and don‚Äôt care to discover the rest of it. I‚Äôve seen this happen pretty much every other day since Twitter had its last excursion, and then the more recent Brazilian excursion. People, basically, celebrating what they themselves believe to be a better platform, and for all intents and purposes, they can do that (even if that platform is a corporate owned entity no better than Twitter)! But, for whatever reason, it‚Äôs always followed by also dunking on people who are minding their own business on the Fediverse. For ‚Ä¶

Reasons!

I want to preface this with something, before I dive into the biggest offenses I‚Äôve seen: I was invited to join Bluesky back when the doors were still closed. Back when it was still an exclusive club, and being more familiar with Mastodon, than Bluesky, I was pretty used to ‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs say, people kinda more actually giving a shit about what they say, when they say it, and how they address others. Much to my dismay, I quickly learned that this is not the average Bluesky experience. Because I didn‚Äôt save any screenshots from when it happened, and I don‚Äôt feel like reliving every intricacy of what exactly went on, I‚Äôll be brief, and explain as simply as possible what took place.

I started following people in and adjacent to the LGBTQ+ community, and, as you know, some people like to post with complete abandon, and zero regard. A ‚Äúpopular‚Äù account, attached to a, then, popular block and mute list creator, used a slur to describe people like her, and people like me, openly, just right on the timeline. Feeling kind of jolted by this, and largely due-in-part to some trauma I‚Äôve had in the past, I asked if it was completely necessary to do that. Or, if some kind of warning could‚Äôve happened (no, I am not talking about the word ‚ÄúQueer‚Äù, just so we‚Äôre straight on that).

This was, apparently, not the right thing to ask.

It was my first week on Bluesky, and I was dogpiled, I was harassed, I was mocked for being traumatized by past events that I had no control over, because of who I was, and how I presented myself to the world (you know, instances of events where harm did, or could have come upon my person).

I had multiple users jump directly into my notifications to make sure I knew that nobody cares about how I feel, about my feelings, and that my experiences mean nothing. That I am alone, and I have to deal with it myself, while others speak, and do as they please.

As you can probably guess, I was a mess around this point. I was kind of ‚Ä¶ reeling. Flashbacks, trauma, anxiety; Feeling like I‚Äôd just joined a social network absolutely full of sociopaths.

Flash forward a year, and both of those original accounts have been pushed off of the website, because, you guessed it: They‚Äôre both abusive people that were given too much benefit of the doubt.

Who could have guessed.

Now: Could I have avoided all of this by just unfollowing the offending account or accounts? Sure. But also I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a lot to ask that people take harmful things, and put them behind a warning. Which is something that usually happens on Mastodon, because, I guess, a larger number of Mastodon users care about other people more than your average Bluesky user?

I don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs a good idea to generalize a whole website of people. But! Impressions were made, and set.

Now, here we are today. Another gaggle of people rejoicing at the growth Bluesky is experiencing due to X being banned in Brazil. Which is good! A website that is owned and operated by a corporate entity, and sponsor, needs growth in order to eventually make money. And, like clockwork, with all of that also comes the random dunking of people who use a much older federated network, that‚Äôs been around since the internet took off. You already know what I‚Äôm talking about, so we‚Äôll just dive right into this, again (I posted about this on my Mastodon account, but I feel like it needed more picking apart).


As a lot of people who read what I write here probably already know, I‚Äôm very passionate about the deconstruction of centralized social media, and the corporate internet. So much so, that I have two machines that run Linux, one that runs MacOS, and none that run Windows. Most of my online activity is on some kind of open-source software, and the corporate tech I do interact with is ‚Ä¶ limited, and usually only for the benefit of what I create, or compose, or make.

Now, I use Linux, and I am by no means a Linux genius, so when I see someone talking about compiling a Linux kernel, I‚Äôm not entirely sure how they‚Äôd accomplish that. I‚Äôve never done it, nor ever considered it. But! I am under the impression that you need some knowledge of the C programming language, and its compilers.

Imagine saying that you need a degree in computer science to choose a Mastodon instance, and to make sure you‚Äôre choosing one with a competent moderation policy, and fully meaning that, wholeheartedly, with a straight face. And to say that in response to someone, basically saying that, your onboarding process for a social network needs to be entirely smooth, without friction, or people will immediately abandon it and just give their data back to their corporate overlords.

I don‚Äôt want to believe that a mass majority of people are so intellectually lazy that they‚Äôd refuse to spend sixty seconds looking at the splash page of a Mastodon instance and going, ‚ÄúHmm. Okay, so they ban nazis and they‚Äôre okay with gay and trans people, awesome!‚Äù I do want to believe that this is just a popular narrative among people who have little specific agendas in mind, but that‚Äôs probably too conspiracy theorist to even begin speaking about.

Like I said in my Mastodon post on this topic, leaving Twitter behind is already creating friction in your social media existence. That a little more is too much, is just ridiculous. People are more happy to jump directly into the arms of another corporation, because all they have to do is write down a username and a password and then forget about it?

Nah, you can‚Äôt be serious, my guy.

But, this all isn‚Äôt even the biggest offense in what‚Äôs essentially a huge thread of people dunking on the fediverse, again, for no reason (I would link to it, but I honestly deactivated my mainline Bluesky account after seeing all of this and I have no interest in visiting their domain, again).


This. This freakin‚Äô attitude again.

‚ÄúOther people‚Äôs feelings aren‚Äôt my problem! I don‚Äôt care about THEM?! GOD.‚Äù

Do you know how difficult it is to push the ‚ÄúCW‚Äù button on Mastodon, and then type your post?

It‚Äôs not hard.

It‚Äôs also not hard to consider other people when you‚Äôre going about your daily life and making decisions.

It is not hard. You cannot convince me that it is.

All this continued attitude from Bluesky proves to me, is that Mastodon users ‚Ä¶ somehow care more about the people around them, than maybe your average user on Bluesky. Which is fucked up. Because the Fediverse has its own issues with nazi instances cropping up at random, and abusive people block evading, and so on, and so forth. But to think it‚Äôs a DUNK, that on Bluesky, you‚Äôre not expected to express empathy for others.

Guys.

Guys, I think I‚Äôm gonna barf into my shoes, and then piss my pants.

I‚Äôm just utterly confused about how we‚Äôve gotten to this point. to this crossroads, where two different websites are having fights with each other, and one of the main points of argument is that ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs too hard to care about other people.

I dunno, fellas, maybe I was right in the first paragraph.

Needless to say, I don‚Äôt really want much to do with Bluesky, and I‚Äôm sure there are perfectly normal and perfectly fine people on the website. But, for the past year this has been a trend, an attitude, that I have only seen coming from Bluesky.

That‚Äôs a red flag.

A continuous, never-ending red flag, that just keeps waving and waving.

I can‚Äôt wait for the ‚ÄúI deleted my Bluesky account today‚Äù posts that will inevitably begin cropping up across the Fediverse. Because, federated social media and the federated internet, is the future, whether Jay at BSKY wants to acknowledge it, or not.


Kay, I‚Äôm done.
entry.summary: I feel like this is something I want to write about here on the Nova Prime, not because it‚Äôs a joyful topic, or something that makes me happy, but because it‚Äôs an overall larger issue that I think‚Äôs been carried over from a website that‚Äôs trained a lot of people to kind of, mentally ‚Ä¶ disregard others, at all expense, for their own personal gain, or comfort. Am I saying that Twitter has accidentally spawned masses of narcissists? Not really. I don‚Äôt think a website and its use for over a decade can alter someone‚Äôs brain chemistry. Or ‚Ä¶ can it?

entry.title: So I Beat POOLS
entry.content:
You remember a while back when I wrote that post on POOLS about how awesome and good I thought the game was? Well, I got to chapter two around that time, and decided to stop playing for a while. Not because the game was bad or anything, but just because it gets under you skin way too easily. Eventually, though, I had to come back, and I had to complete it.

And that I did.

I‚Äôm going to spoil a bunch of stuff here, but I‚Äôm assuming that‚Äôs okay, because Backrooms related games and media are kinda niche, and when it comes to horror, this is especially niche.

Usually, when I tried to play this game, I would do it late at night, in complete silence ‚Ä¶ for some reason. And that made it pretty hard to work my way through. Don‚Äôt even get me started on The Complex: Expedition. Despite its harmless entity (that I know of), I find that game just as terrifying.

It‚Äôs all the low humming, the scratches, the howling of dark wind in an endless tunnel.

But I did it.

I pushed through, with my pinky on the shift key, the entire time.

There were freaky moments. Funny moments. And sometimes, awe-inspiring moments.

And then it came to an end, with the silent protagonist setting their camera down upon a table, mannequins encroaching upon you from one of two paths behind you, and another arm holding a door open. But then the view cuts to a recording, the door shuts, and whoever‚Äôs viewing the tape of your actions hits the stop button, and credits roll.

Pretty confusing, right?

I don‚Äôt think so.

Throughout POOLS, there is a lot of imagery. It‚Äôs, of course, based on the Backrooms. And the pool rooms are a level known in the liminal maze. Some may also know it as Sublimity (you also get a glimpse of the actual Backrooms in POOLS, along with some other pieces of levels dreamed up by the fandom, such as Eternal Suburbia). The developers though, they only say it‚Äôs based on the Backrooms, and I think I understand why we‚Äôre making that distinction here. Because it is the backrooms, but it‚Äôs also something else.

It‚Äôs a work of art.

It‚Äôs purgatory.

It‚Äôs an allegory for abuse, and the victim of that abuse fighting to escape it, and failing. Fighting in isolation, and trauma, reminded at every turn what they did to you, and when there‚Äôs a light at the end of the tunnel and you think you‚Äôre finally out of the never-ending spiral, it goes out and disappears. And then the darkness pulls you back in.

Where does this inkling come from, though? Some have already said that they believe this to be an allegory for such things. That this has to be about abuse, or something. I think someone even mentioned they thought it was about CSA, due to some depictions of a child‚Äôs drawings on the walls, big black letters scrawled across a picture that reads, ‚ÄúNOTHING,‚Äù a single lonely house that appears to you toward the end, and then endless copies of it, and the appearance of very large mannequins screaming, viewing other mannequins in compromising, embarrassing positions, pointing, staring, mouth-agape in horror.

Whatever type of abuse it is, I think this game is definitely telling a story, whether real or fiction, and it‚Äôs all right in front of you the whole time.

The innocent rubber ducks sitting around in the water that are somehow terrifying. The pool slides that seem to be in random places that beg to be jumped into, as absurd as that is, while you‚Äôre lost in a horrifying complex.

The mixture of innocence, and despair.

Of lightheartedness, and terror.

POOLS takes something that really has no meaning, other than to terrify, and turns it into something that has ‚Ä¶ a very deep message. Something you have to decode yourself, or not. It‚Äôs entirely up to the player, I think. And that‚Äôs one more thing that just makes this game so good.

I could be entirely wrong, though, and this could be one of many ways to interpret the game. And that‚Äôs okay. Because POOLS isn‚Äôt just a game, it‚Äôs a work of art, and it asks that you experience it. Nothing more.

entry.title: NaNoWriMo Weaponizes Social Justice Language in Endorsement of AI

link.title: NaNoWriMo Weaponizes Social Justice Language in Endorsement of AI

entry.content:
It‚Äôs the second day of my little tiny vacation, and I‚Äôve woken up at the bright and early hour of 11 in the morning. I log onto social media to check my notifications and see what‚Äôs happening, and ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm immediately alerted that those behind NaNoWriMo (National Novel Writing Month) have endorsed using theft-machines (AI) to generate books and stories, while weaponizing social justice language in order to emotionally manipulate their readers and writers.

404 Media wrote a fairly neutral article on the matter that doesn‚Äôt appear to take any position whatsoever, but I‚Äôm linking them here anyway, in order to contextualize who NaNoWriMo was, and is.

NaNoWriMo started as a group writing project in the ‚Äò90s with the goal of writing a 50,000-word manuscript in one month (November), but in 2005, NaNoWriMo became a nonprofit organization that takes donations and runs fundraising campaigns.

But, let‚Äôs now take a look at their reasoning, and then tear those reasons to shreds. I‚Äôll be calling NaNoWriMo ‚ÄúNNW‚Äù from here on out in this post, just because it‚Äôs easier to type than an abbreviation with annoying capitalization.

NNW says that condemning AI in writing is classist:

Not all writers have the financial ability to hire humans to help at certain phases of their writing. For some writers, the decision to use AI is a practical, not an ideological, one. The financial ability to engage a human for feedback and review assumes a level of privilege that not all community members possess.

It‚Äôs true that, as writers and authors who don‚Äôt have access to thousands of dollars, it can be a hard time getting outside opinions and help on your writing. But, here‚Äôs the thing: You can still write a story, or a novel, without using machines that rip off other authors in order to edit and proofread (if you can call feeding your work into an LLM ‚Äúediting‚Äù and ‚Äúproofreading‚Äù). As an independent author, myself, I have friends, and sometimes I‚Äôll conscript them to give me some opinions on what I‚Äôve written. I also extensively comb over my writing (now, at least) when I‚Äôm putting a book together. Hence the reason it‚Äôs been taking me well over a year to make progress on my next book, Dissolution Protocol. I want to make something really good.

And it takes a lot of practice, and time, to become effective at spotting errors and issues in your own writing.

But here‚Äôs the thing: That‚Äôs fine! What‚Äôs the rush? The act of creating art is and always has been a slow-burn process of practicing, learning, and both failure and success. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with that! That‚Äôs how art is! And introducing AI into the matter cuts that out completely. All of it.

And that‚Äôs not to mention all of the other resources available to independent writers and authors. Join a discussion forum of writers and readers! Post snippets! There are so many online avenues you can use to find help with your writing that don‚Äôt cost you a dime, and you don‚Äôt have to rip off anyone in order to utilize them.

NNW also says that condemning AI in writing is ableist:

Not all brains have same abilities and not all writers function at the same level of education or proficiency in the language in which they are writing. Some brains and ability levels require outside help or accommodations to achieve certain goals. The notion that all writers ‚Äúshould‚Äú be able to perform certain functions independently or is a position that we disagree with wholeheartedly. There is a wealth of reasons why individuals can‚Äôt ‚Äúsee‚Äù the issues in their writing without help.

In my opinion, this is the part where they get real manipulative, because now we‚Äôre using disabled people as our reason for saying it‚Äôs totally fine to use these planet-destroying bots to write for you (LLMs are more and more increasingly power hungry, so much so that Microsoft is considering building nuclear reactors to power them, and many current LLMs are burning tons and tons of fossil fuels in order to operate).

Yes, people sometimes need outside accommodations for reading and writing, like screen readers, and special keyboards, and, as I mentioned in my thoughts above, community forums where readers and writers collaborate together to troubleshoot their own work. Saying, ‚Äúnot all brains have the same abilities‚Äù in your endorsement of these machines is exactly how a psychopath would attempt to convince you that cutting off your own hand is beneficial to you, somehow.

Now, to be fair, this is what they actually say right at the start of their post on Zendesk:

NaNoWriMo does not explicitly support any specific approach to writing, nor does it explicitly condemn any approach, including the use of AI.

or, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt explicitly support any specific approach to writing, and we don‚Äôt condemn any approach, such as AI, but also, here‚Äôs why we fully endorse using AI.‚Äù

I‚Äôm gonna be real with you, chief. I have used text-based AI. I‚Äôve used it like Google to see if it could answer questions better and faster than a Google search would. Because, despite my grievances with most LLMs, and especially the image-generation machines that are completely and entirely based on theft and disenfranchisement, I don‚Äôt think these things are going anywhere. I think there are some limited uses for text-based AI. Like, you could open up, let‚Äôs say, ChatGPT and say, ‚ÄúHey, what are some writing prompts that might be interesting?‚Äù or, ‚ÄúWhat are some resources I could use to get outside opinions and help on my writing?‚Äù

And sometimes, you do actually get decent answers. I just wouldn‚Äôt trust whatever the hell Google‚Äôs developing.

Now, let‚Äôs take a look at their continued opinions in regard to general access issues:

All of these considerations exist within a larger system in which writers don‚Äôt always have equal access to resources along the chain. For example, underrepresented minorities are less likely to be offered traditional publishing contracts, which places some, by default, into the indie author space, which inequitably creates upfront cost burdens that authors who do not suffer from systemic discrimination may have to incur.

So, we‚Äôre continuing to emotionally manipulate people by, instead of using disabled people this time, we‚Äôre going to use marginalized people, such as the LGBTQ+ community.

Yes, yes, finding an agent is hard. Getting a contract is even harder. In the years I‚Äôve been writing fiction (since 2008), I‚Äôve rebuffed the idea completely. Especially after, more recently, seeing examples of literary agents openly suggesting stealing an author‚Äôs query for themselves.

The world is a vampire. A pimple-infested, gout infected, disease ridden, vampire.

But, with this further explanation of their stance, NNW speaks as though being an ‚Äúindie author‚Äù is not desirable, that it‚Äôs lesser, and I couldn‚Äôt disagree more.

Since I started writing, those who do have contracts, and who do have agents, have always taken to social media to speak like the privileged snobs some of them are. Saying that community-sourced editing and proofreading from authors who take to publishing themselves through avenues like Smashwords, aren‚Äôt as good, or are ‚Äúlazy.‚Äù That you shouldn‚Äôt pay any attention to an author‚Äôs work, if it isn‚Äôt coming out of one of the big six.

And, sadly, authors utilizing AI to write books for them are only going to make independent publishing that much harder, because the optics around self publishing were already dark, and muddy, partially because of the gate-keeper jerks who speak like this.

You can be an independent author, and you can write a decent story, without using machines that not only steal from other writers, but will absolutely vacuum up the work you feed into it, in order to further compound this problem. And I‚Äôm going to say that again, so that it‚Äôs clear, you should not feed your work into an LLM (an AI), unless you want it stolen from you.

I can only imagine that the reason NNW has taken this stance, is because they must have suddenly received funding from some kind of Silicon Valley venture capital, right?

Right?

Anyway, those are the most important points I wanted to touch on in light of these, frankly, idiotic takes coming from NNW. If you‚Äôre going to endorse AI, you can at least do it without speaking to writers and readers like Hannibal-fucking-Lector, manipulating them into sitting down at the dinner table and prepping their own brain for consumption.

Update: And here you have it, NaNoWriMo is sponsored by a company that utilizes AI.

entry.title: Embrace, Extend, Extinguish (Repeat)
entry.content:
I‚Äôve written on here before about Threads and how:

  • I think it‚Äôs totally fine for people to join if they‚Äôre too bamboozled by the process of a picking an instance on Mastodon, or some other piece of ActivityPub software (even though I still can‚Äôt really fathom just exactly how it seems hard to some).
  • The southern division of public policy has a Project 2025 author on its team, and Meta has yet to even remotely acknowledge this to the public. Just exactly how much influence this living turd has on Threads is questionable. For all I know it could only be Facebook (judging by the way Facebook looks nowadays).
  • It‚Äôs algorithm is like a drunk person having mood swings, in that, if you even so much as slightly interact with a topic, that‚Äôs the only thing you see for the entire next day.
  • And that there are groups of instances on the Fediverse extremely dedicated to not only blocking federation from Threads themselves, but essentially utilizing peer pressure as a weapon in order to get others to do so, as well.

On that last point, though, I‚Äôve spoken about the little ‚Äúblack list‚Äù built by veganism.social that basically lists every federated server they can see, and whether or not they‚Äôre blocking Threads (again, peer pressure, and I wish people would stop acting like we‚Äôre all mentally still in high school). I find things like this distasteful. Have your opinion, your feelings, and what you think is right, and stop forcing it onto other people, unless of course we‚Äôre talking discrimination, hate crimes, or what-have-you ‚Ä¶ I mean, obviously, you should make sure people know those things are bad.

But Threads?

Right now I‚Äôm seeing it as kind of a gray area.

There are people on there I haven‚Äôt seen in years, that I was originally following on Twitter. Tons of LGBTQ+ people, and other people I wouldn‚Äôt ever call ‚Äúbad‚Äù. And then, you know, the trolls, weirdos, and one-off accounts, and oh yeah, also, the spam accounts intentionally setup to grift engagement.

That‚Äôs not what I‚Äôm writing this post about, today, though.

Today it‚Äôs about the ethos of ‚Äúembrace, extend, extinguish‚Äù that all started with Google and XMPP. Basically, Google integrated its instant messaging protocol with XMPP, and then decided, like they do with every project that isn‚Äôt an immediate groundbreaking successful thing, and backed out. The problem with this, is that Google‚Äôs integration was highly anticipated, and this drew a lot more people to XMPP, and then this also essentially ‚Äúkilled it.‚Äù I don‚Äôt really know if you can say it‚Äôs dead, though, because I literally can see people linking to their own usernames for XMPP on their Mastodon profiles, right now, as I‚Äôm typing this.

The fear revolving around Threads and federation with ActivityPub, is ‚Ä¶ uhm, that people might get too excited about this, and everyone might federate with Threads, and then Threads might pull out and extinguish interest in ActivityPub. That, and Meta isn‚Äôt so great at moderating Threads. But ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt really see how that‚Äôs a problem for Mastodon, when as admins and moderators, you can manually silence bad accounts, and you should, regardless of where they‚Äôre coming from. An interesting thing I‚Äôve seen on Wafrn, though, is that the federated Tumblr alternative makes federating with Threads an account-level, opt-in, and I think that‚Äôs actually really genius. The decision should absolutely be in the hands of the user.

But I have some opinions on XMPP and its eventual perceived crash, and whether Meta is copy/pasting what Google did here.

First of all, as much as I loved Aol Instant Messenger, and instant messaging in the nineties ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs dead, guys. I don‚Äôt know about you, or anyone else, but I can hardly find enough interest in Discord and my Steam friends list to keep up with them enough to actively talk to people for long periods of time. I ‚Ä¶ kind of just use social media for that. You know, that thing that started with Myspace and only became bigger until it ruled our entire lives?

Nowadays, I kind of don‚Äôt really like anyone outside of my family having immediate access to me. I‚Äôm reclusive, and I‚Äôm battling things in my head that make it hard for me to break out of my own shell, and you think I‚Äôm going to go out of my way to actively talk to a bunch of people instantly and all of the time.

Nuh uh.

You see, I mean, sure, Google deciding to graveyard federation with XMPP likely harmed it, even if just a little bit. But I think the overarching problem here is just that, instant messaging isn‚Äôt really the thing nowadays, and I think it‚Äôs always kind of been on the way out.

Social media, micro-blogging, you think that‚Äôd go away on the fediverse on the off-chance that Meta kills Threads, or pulls out of ActivityPub?

AP‚Äôs been around since the early 2000s, and yeah, sure, it has this reputation of being a Linux-user‚Äôs heaven, and full of dudes who hate people who make things (like music, art, etc), but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs ever going anywhere. At this point, Twitter is basically the only major platform that isn‚Äôt federated, or touting decentralization, and it‚Äôs dying.

But even in the off-chance that Meta does a select-all and delete on its ActivityPub integration, I think apps like Mastodon would definitely still be standing. Because, as of writing this, plenty of people aren‚Äôt even federating with Threads, and most of the people I see and interact with on the fediverse value a user-owned social network more than anything else on the web. Whether Threads is there or not, for many, is purely inconsequential in the grander scheme of things. And a lot of users on Threads don‚Äôt even know what the hell Mastodon even is.

Post by @thebrianpenny
View on Threads

I don‚Äôt think I have to, but I just want to point out real quick that Mastodon is not a company, and ActivityPub, or, ‚Äúthe fediverse‚Äù, as stated before, has existed for decades. That the Bluesky devs suddenly, just two days ago, decided to call the network of keys accessing their servers ‚Äúthe atmosphere‚Äù is more or less just another way I feel they‚Äôre kind of cherry-picking ideas from a concept that has existed well before they decided they wanted to be Twitter 2.0.

We talk about Bluesky getting users, but Bluesky is part of an open social internet called "The Atmosphere" where other people can make their own apps, including their own versions of Bluesky. Bluesky isn't growing; the Atmosphere is! You're not "our" users; you're a part of a shared place.

— Paul Frazee (@pfrazee.com) Aug 31, 2024 at 8:43 PM

But anyway .. embrace, extend, extinguish, or just fear-mongering, with some legit concerns about corporations, and their goals?

You decide, I suppose.

A lot of what I say about some of these networks might sound negative, or pessimistic, but I really do actually enjoy watching it all shift back and forth. I like that the internet is having a power-struggle to figure out where the ‚Äúplace to be‚Äù is now. Because none of them will win. The ‚Äúplace to be‚Äù is wherever you want, and it should‚Äôve never been just one website, like I sad in my ‚Äúblog day‚Äù post.
